In the 2016–17 season they won the [[FA Women's Premier League Southern Division]] and a subsequent playoff, gaining promotion to the [[FA Women's Super League 2]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/spursladies/news/spurs-ladies-win-play-off-290517/|title=Spurs Ladies all set for Women's Super League 29 May 2017 – News |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur Football Club|accessdate=30 June 2018}} ==Honours== {{see also|Tottenham Hotspur F.C. [[1972 UEFA Cup Final|1971–72]], [[1984 UEFA Cup Final|1983–84]] ==Statistics and records== [[File:TottenhamHotspurFC League Performance.svg|thumb|upright=1.6|Chart of Tottenham's performance since joining the Football League in 1908]] {{Main|List of Tottenham Hotspur F.C. records and statistics}} {{details|List of Tottenham Hotspur F.C. seasons}} [[Steve Perryman]] holds the appearance record for Spurs, having played 854 games for the club between 1969 and 1986, of which 655 were league matches.{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisplymouth.co.uk/news/Amigos-lined-Grecians-fundraiser/article-1418626-detail/article.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130114041144/http://www.thisisplymouth.co.uk/news/Amigos-lined-Grecians-fundraiser/article-1418626-detail/article.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 January 2013|title=Three Amigos lined up for Grecians fundraiser|date=14 October 2009|work=[[The Herald (Plymouth)|The Herald]]|accessdate=22 November 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/archive/Steve-Perryman-article941.html|title=Steve Perryman|work=Daily Mirror|accessdate=22 November 2009}} [[Jimmy Greaves]] holds the club goal scoring record with 266 goals in 380 league, cup and European appearances.{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/history/legends/jimmygreaves.html |title=Legends: Jimmy Greaves |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur Football Club |accessdate=22 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003135756/http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/history/legends/jimmygreaves.html |archivedate=3 October 2009 }} Tottenham's record league win is 9–0 against [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] in the Second Division on 22 October 1977.{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/history/great_games/spursvbristolrovers1977.html|title=22 October 1977: Spurs 9–0 Bristol Rovers|publisher=Tottenham Hotspur Football Club|accessdate=22 November 2009}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601077&sid=aJRyb5rocCJI|title=Defoe gets five goals as Tottenham defeats Wigan 9–1|last=Cone|first=James|date=22 November 2009|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 November 2009}} The club's record cup victory came on 3 February 1960 with a 13–2 win over [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] in the FA Cup.{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/history/great_games/spurs13crewe21960.html|title=3 February 1960: Spurs 13–2 Crewe Alexandra|publisher=Tottenham Hotspur Football Club|accessdate=22 November 2009}} Spurs' biggest top-flight victory came against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on 22 November 2009, when they won 9–1 with Jermain Defoe scoring five goals.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8365091.stm|title=Tottenham 9–1 Wigan|last=Fletcher|first=Paul|date=22 November 2009|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 November 2009}} The club's record defeat is an 8–0 loss to [[1. FC Köln]] in the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup|Intertoto Cup]] on 22 July 1995.{{cite web |url=http://uk.uefa.com/teamsandplayers/teams/club=1652/profile/index.html |title=UEFA.com – Tottenham |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=28 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130527194818/http://uk.uefa.com/teamsandplayers/teams/club=1652/profile/index.html |archivedate=27 May 2013 }} The record home attendance at White Hart Lane was 75,038 on 5 March 1938 in a [[1937–38 FA Cup|cup tie]] against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/white-hart-lane-final-statistics-150517/ |title=White Hart Lane – Final Statistics|date= 15 May 2017 |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur Football Club |accessdate=30 June 2018}} The highest recorded home attendances were at their temporary home, [[Wembley Stadium]], due to its higher capacity – 85,512 spectators turned up on 2 November 2016 for the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League]] game against [[Bayer Leverkusen]],{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37839379 | title=Tottenham Hotspur 0 – 1 Bayer 04 Leverkusen | publisher=BBC Sport | date=2 November 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2018}} while 83,222 attended the [[North London Derby]] against Arsenal on 10 February 2018 which is the highest attendance recorded for any Premier League game.{{cite news |url=http://metro.co.uk/2018/02/10/harry-kane-talismanic-tottenham-sink-arsenal-front-record-breaking-wembley-crowd-7302499/ |title=Harry Kane talismanic as Tottenham sink Arsenal in front of record-breaking Wembley crowd |first=Tom |last=Olver|date= 10 February 2018|work=Metro |accessdate=30 June 2018}} ==Players== ===Current squad=== {{updated|1 February 2019}}{{cite
